title: PTS
description: Test your knowledge of essential safety procedures and protocols for working on or near railway tracks.

questions.question: What defines being 'on or near the line'?
options: Being within 5 meters of the running line with fences between you and the line
Being on the line itself or within 3 meters of the running line with no fences or permanent structures between you and the line
Being anywhere between the boundary fences regardless of distance from the track
Being on the platform edge when a train is approaching
questions.explanation: Being 'on or near the line' means being on the line itself or within 3 meters (10 feet) of the running line and there are no fences or permanent structures between you and the running line.

questions.question: What is the minimum safe distance that must be maintained from overhead line equipment (OHLE)?
options: 1.25 meters (4 feet)
2 meters (6 feet 6 inches)
2.75 meters (9 feet)
3.25 meters (10 feet 6 inches)
questions.explanation: The minimum safe distance that must be maintained from the OHLE is 2.75 meters (9 feet).

questions.question: What is the MAPS procedure when a train approaches?
options: Move to a position of safety, Alert others, Position yourself facing the train, Signal to the driver
Monitor the train, Assess the speed, Prepare warning signals, Sound horn
Move to a position of safety, Acknowledge approaching train, Place any tools down, Stay in position until train passes and no others are approaching
Move quickly, Avoid the 4 foot, Position yourself in a refuge, Signal when clear
questions.explanation: The MAPS procedure stands for: Move to a position of safety, Acknowledge approaching train, Place any tools down on the floor, Stay in a position of safety until train has passed and you are sure no other trains are approaching.

questions.question: If you are caught between adjacent lines and a train approaches, what should you do?
options: Run along the track until you find a position of safety
Lay face down in the 4 foot area until the train passes
Wave to alert the driver to stop the train
Lay face down in the 6 foot, 10 foot or cess, gather loose clothing underneath you, and don't move until the train passes
questions.explanation: If caught between adjacent lines when a train approaches, you should lay face down in the 6 foot, 10 foot, or CESS (NOT IN THE 4 FOOT), gather any loose clothing underneath you, and do not move until the train has passed and you are sure no other trains are approaching.

questions.question: What does a red and white squares sign with 'warning limited clearance' indicate?
options: No position of safety for the length of this structure; do not attempt to pass while a train is approaching
No position of safety, but there are refuges on the opposite side of the railway line
Reduced speed limit in operation for this section
Warning of electrical hazards in this area
questions.explanation: Red and white squares with 'warning limited clearance' written on it means there is no position of safety for the length of this structure and you must not attempt to pass while a train is approaching.

questions.question: How would you identify a COSS on site?
options: White armband with red letters
Red armband with white letters
Blue armband with white letters
White armband with blue letters
questions.explanation: A COSS (Controller of Site Safety) can be identified by a BLUE ARMBAND with COSS written in WHITE LETTERS.

questions.question: What is the correct position of safety for a train traveling at 120mph?
options: 1.25 meters (4 feet) from the running line
2 meters (6 feet 6 inches) from the running line
2.75 meters (9 feet) from the running line
There is no safe working distance at this speed
questions.explanation: For trains running between 101-125mph, the position of safety is 2 meters (6 foot 6 inches) from the running line.

questions.question: When crossing railway lines, what is the correct technique?
options: Cross diagonally to minimize time spent on the track
Cross at 90 degrees, stepping on the rails for stability
Cross at 90 degrees, walking ballast to ballast, avoiding stepping on sleepers, rails, and points
Cross running from ballast to ballast to minimize time spent on the track
questions.explanation: To safely cross a line, cross at a 90-degree angle, walk ballast to ballast, and avoid stepping on sleepers, rails, and points.

questions.question: What is the voltage of the OHLE?
options: 750 volts DC
11,000 volts AC
25,000 volts AC
33,000 volts AC
questions.explanation: The OHLE carries 25,000 volts AC and must be considered live at all times.

questions.question: After an OHLE tripping, how long before the ECO attempts to re-energise?
options: 5 minutes
10 minutes
30 minutes
Immediately
questions.explanation: After an OHLE tripping, the ECO will try to re-energise IMMEDIATELY.

questions.question: What is a PICEI in regard to overhead lines?
options: Person Investigating Circuit Electrical Issues
Protective Insulation for Cable and Electrical Infrastructure
Person In Charge of Electrical Isolation
Primary Inspection of Conductors and Electrical Interfaces
questions.explanation: In regard to overhead lines, a 'PICEI' is the Person In Charge of Electrical Isolation.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the orange CANT line at cab roof height?
options: Indicates the maximum loading gauge for freight
Shows the maximum height of the pantograph
Indicates you cannot go above this line if OHL are still live
Marks the boundary between different electrification zones
questions.explanation: The orange line at cab roof height is the CANT line - you cannot go above this line if OHL are still live.

questions.question: You have been granted an emergency isolation of the OHLE and your relief arrives. What must you do?
options: Brief them and leave immediately
Inform the signaller and then leave
Contact the ECO, identify yourself, state your relief has arrived, pass the phone to your relief, and do not leave until you are officially relieved
Sign the handover book and leave
questions.explanation: If granted an emergency isolation and your relief arrives, contact the ECO, identify yourself, state that your relief has arrived, and pass the phone to your relief who will be taking over the emergency isolation. DO NOT LEAVE BEFORE YOU ARE RELIEVED.

questions.question: Which is NOT one of the 4 hand signals you could use to stop a train in an emergency?
options: Red flag
Red light
Any light waved vigorously
Both arms extended horizontally to the sides
questions.explanation: The 4 hand signals you could use to stop a train in an emergency are: Red flag, Red light, Any light waved vigorously, and Two arms raised straight up in the air. Extending arms horizontally is not one of these signals.

questions.question: What does a blue and white squares sign with 'warning no refuges' indicate?
options: No position of safety in any direction for the length of this structure
No position of safety for the length of this structure, but there ARE positions of safety on the opposite side of the railway line
No protection for workers in this area
No train services operating in this section
questions.explanation: A blue and white squares sign with 'warning no refuges' means there is no position of safety for the length of this structure; however, there ARE positions of safety or refuges ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE RAILWAY LINE.
